metadata.title: Review of micro/nano machining by utilizing elliptical vibration cutting

sections.text:
Textured surfaces with sophisticated micro/nano structures can provide interesting and advanced functions. In order to promote those unique functions into the practical use, high performance manufacturing technologies are required. Nowadays, elliptical vibration cutting (EVC) is attracting more and more attentions due to its excellent machining performances, especially the advantageous in the precision machining of difficult-to-cut materials. The emphasis on this literature review is the micro/nano machining technology by applying EVC. The development of the EVC technology is simply introduced, and then the advantageousness of EVC in the machining process is explored in detail. As following, the development of different EVC devices are introduced, and the applications of the micro/nano structure fabrication is detailedly expatiated by applying the different types of elliptical vibrators. By controlling the motion of the ultra-precision machine tool itself, the micro/nano structure can be accurately fabricated on various workpiece materials with the reduction of cutting forces, burr generation, tool wear, et al. in EVC process. Moreover, a unique amplitude control sculpturing method, where the depth of cut is arbitrary changed by controlling the vibration amplitude in the machining process, is introduced. By applying the amplitude control sculpturing method, ultra-precision micro/nano structures can be efficiently sculptured especially on the difficult-to-cut materials. Finally, the elliptical vibration texturing process is also explored in the fast micro/nano machining of the simple and regular structures. The EVC technology is expected to promote the development of micro/nano machining process in the actual industrial applications.
Keywords: Micro/nano structures, Elliptical vibration cutting, Elliptical vibrator, Amplitude control sculpturing, Elliptical vibration texturing
1. Introduction
Structured surfaces with sophisticated micro/nano structures can provide
advanced and useful functions. These micro/nano-structured surfaces can exhibit a number of novel and excellent functions and features as compared with just simple smooth surfaces. To achieve the maximum benefit from the structured surfaces, application technologies of the micro/nano-structured surfaces have been a fascinating research topic in the last few decades. Structured surfaces have been increasingly demanded in various applications, such as optics [1-3], solar energy technology [4-6], bioengineering [7-9], self-cleaning [10, 11], advanced manufacturing [12-15], and so on [16, 17]. To promote widespread use of the structured surfaces, the manufacturing technology of micro/nano structures for a variety of materials is absolutely essential. When the feature size of the designed structure is downscaled into micrometer or nanometer level, those fabrications may become extremely challenging. To overcome this problem, numerous methods for the micro/nano structure fabrication have been proposed so far. Typical methods are proposed, including the lithographic machining, the laser beam machining, the focused ion beam machining, the electron beam machining, the electrical discharge machining, the diamond machining, and so on.
Lithography, focused ion beam machining and electron beam machining play a
critical role in micro/nano-structure fabrication. These processes are advantageous to fabricate highly-dense micro/nano structures with a high aspect ratio and straight sidewalls. The feature size can be downscaled into tens of nanometers or even several nanometers. However, these manufacturing technologies are not available for a large structure height of several hundred micrometers due to their low removal rate and time consuming nature. The machining efficiency is improved by applying laser machining, however it is difficult to fabricate highly-dense nanometer-scale structures due to the physical restriction in the minimum dimension of focused laser beam. The electrical discharge machining just can be applied to the machining of electrically conductive materials, and the feature size is limited by the geometries of the electrode tool. Considering the mechanical micromachining technologies, micro grinding is not available for dense micro/nano structure fabrication due to the size restriction of grinding wheel, especially the radius of wheel tip. And also, it is difficult to fabricate the sophisticated three-dimensional (3D) structures by applying the micro grinding process. On the other hand, diamond cutting has a large dimension span in the micro/nano structure fabrication, which is flexible and capable for many different designs. Ultra-precision diamond cutting is superior to produce ultra-precision and
sophisticated structures in the feature size of several to hundreds micrometers practically. It also has many advantages of high geometrical accuracy, good surface quality and high machining efficiency. Diamond cutting allows a high degree of freedom for the structural design as compared with other methods, and thus it has been widely used especially for plasitic molding applications of a variety of optical elements. Combining with mass production process such as injection molding and compression molding, diamond cutting becomes available for manufacturing of high-quality and low-cost consumer products, and hence, quickly popularizes among the related industries.
Ultra-precision diamond cutting is usually applied to the fabrication of precision
parts on plasitic materials, such as the soft metals including oxygen-free copper, brass, aluminum alloy, polymeric material such as PMMA, electroless nickel-phosphorus plating [18], and so on. Recently, ultra-precision dies and molds made of difficult-to-cut materials, i.e., hardened steel and tungsten carbide, are greatly required for the mass production of functional elements with micro/nano structures, especially in optical industry. However, the conventional diamond cutting is not applicable directly to steel materials due to the extremely chemical tool wear [19]. Many researchers have dedicated to attain the conventional diamond machining of steel materials with suppressing tool wear propagation [20-23]. However, none of these methods was found applicable to industrial applications. In addition, tungsten carbide is a typically hard and brittle material, and its ductile machining is extremely difficult by the conventional diamond cutting due to the generations of brittle fracture on machined workpiece surface and the excessive tool damage [24]. On the other hand, micro/nano structured components are mass-produced by glass molding and injection molding with complicated micro/nano structured molds/dies made of hardened steel and tungsten carbide. Hence, advanced diamond cutting technology is highly required for the micro/nano structure fabrication on hardened steel, tungsten carbide, and other difficult-to-cut materials. For the last few decades, ultrasonic vibration cutting technology has been successfully applied to the difficult-to-cut materials machining [25, 26]. In particular, Shamoto and Moriwaki [27] proposed a new cutting method named as elliptical vibration cutting (EVC). The feasibility of steel material machining, tungsten carbide machining and several other difficult-to-cut materials machining was verified by applying EVC with the single crystal diamond (SCD) tools. Furthermore, Suzuki et al. [28] proposed a unique micro/nano sculpturing method by controlling the vibration amplitude in the EVC process. It is expected to enable highly-efficient fabrication of sophisticated micro/nano structures on the difficult-to-cut materials. EVC technology is a kind of novel and advanced
manufacture technology in the precisely industrial application. It is hoped to be superior to fabricate the micro/nano structures not only on the easy-to-cut materials, but also on the difficult-to-cut materials by applying the SCD tool.
In this review paper, the development of EVC technology is introduced firstly, and
then the properties of EVC process are expounded in detail. Moreover, the benefits of micro/nano machining are explored by applying the EVC. Following that, the different types of developed elliptical vibrators, i.e., the non-resonant and the resonant elliptical vibrators, are introduced. And then, the applications of micro/nano structure fabrication are introduced by applying the different elliptical vibrators. The different manufacturing methods for micro/nano structure fabrication, including the slow several of machine tool controlling, the amplitude control sculpturing and the elliptical vibration texturing, are explained in detail. For the ultra-precision micro/nano machining process, EVC is hoped as a kind of potential superior technologies for the industrial applications.
2. Linear vibration cutting and elliptical vibration cutting
Vibration assisted cutting (VAC) technique is an emerging cutting process that
has been increasingly applied in the manufacturing industry since the 1960s [29]. In the early developing era of this technology, only vibration assisted machining with a linear vibration motion in the nominal cutting direction (or slightly inclined with respect to the nominal cutting direction) is commonly practiced by researchers. This type of VAC is named as “linear vibration cutting (LVC)”. The nominal cutting speed is set to be lower than the maximum tool vibration speed so that the tool can be separated from the workpiece in each vibration cycle. Figure 1 illustrates the process of LVC.
numerically clarified before carrying out the actual cutting, i.e., the theoretical roughness, the minimum clearance angle and rake angle. As shown in Fig. 2, in each cycle of the elliptical vibration, the tool starts to cut the workpiece at time t1, and then the workpiece material is removed in the form of a chip. After the tangential direction of the tool trajectory becomes parallel to the rake face, the cutting tool separates from the chip at t5. The nominal cutting speed is set to be lower than the maximum vibration speed in the nominal cutting direction, ensuring that the tool is separated from the workpiece in each vibration cycle. When the tangential direction of the tool trajectory exceeds the shear direction of the material removing, the friction direction between the tool rake face and the chip is reversed as compared with that in the ordinary cutting process. This reverse of the friction leads to an increase in the nominal shear angle, resulting in significant decreases of the chip thickness and the average cutting forces [27, 40, 41]. With these benefits, it is theoretically and experimentally clarified that the burr generation and the regenerative chatter can be suppressed [42-44] in the EVC process. Additionally, the tool cuts the surface that is finished in the previous vibration cycle in the EVC process. The actual uncut chip thickness in each vibration cycle becomes generally smaller as compared with the nominal depth of cut. In other words, the process is similar to that of micro milling. As compared with the OC process, the average pushing stress and bending stress in workpiece deformation zone are effectively decreased in EVC process, which is much advantageous to the micro/nano structure manufacturing. Moreover, due to the separation in each vibration cycle, the contact surfaces of the cutting edge and the workpiece can be exposed into the surrounding gas and/or the cutting fluid, resulting in cooling of the tool and workpieces. As a result, not only the thermo-chemical wear but also the adhesion and diffusion between the workpiece and the diamond tool can be supressed efficiently. This technology is tested in industries mainly for ultra-precision diamond cutting of dies, molds, and optical parts. Through constant development in two decades, this novel method has been proved to be a promising method in terms of almost all cutting performances as compared with the OC and LVC methods in cutting various materials, especially the difficult-to-cut materials. Ultra-precision machining of difficult-to-cut materials, such as hardened steel [45-48], tungsten alloy [49], sintered tungsten carbide [50-54], fibre-reinforced polymer [55], Molybdenum [56], Co-Cr-Mo alloy [57], Plexiglas [58] and other various materials [59], were realized by applying the EVC technology.
Fig. 2. Elliptical vibration cutting process [40, 41].
Based on the successful cutting performance of EVC in the practical applications,
Suzuki et al. [28] explored further possibilities of functional surface machining on difficult-to-cut materials by applying EVC, and proposed a unique micro/nano sculpturing method. In this proposed method, vibration amplitude of the elliptical vibration is actively controlled while machining. Because of this amplitude control, the depth of cut can be changed rapidly without the fast tool servo (FTS) but as being controlled by the conventional FTS technology. In other words, the EVC technology is already equipped with a FTS function by itself. Nowadays, EVC is attracting more and more attention due to its excellent machining performances, especially the advantageous in the precision micro/nano machining process.
3. Non-resonant elliptical vibration cutting
3.1 The development of non-resonant elliptical vibrators
The initial elliptical vibrator is proposed in 1994 by Shamoto and Moriwaki [27].
The tool is vibrated by two separately piezoelectric actuators (PZT) arranged at a right angle. With sinusoidally controlling the motion of PZT, the vibration locus is generated on the tool tip by converting the linear expansion and contraction of the PZT. This elliptical vibrator is able to work at a continuous frequency range, which is quite different from the natural vibration frequencies. This kind of vibration device is named as non-resonant elliptical vibrator. Although the trajectory of the vibration locus can be controlled easily and precisely, the working frequency is not high due to the low stiffness of the mechanical structure. Figure 3 illustrates two types of non-resonant elliptical vibrator used in the previous researches. Shamoto and Moriwaki [27] firstly applied the vertical stacked vibrator to investigate the EVC process directly inside a
scanning electron microscope (SEM). As compared with the OC, the beneficial properties of the EVC is confirmed, such as decreasing the chip thickness and the cutting forces, suppressing the burr generation, increasing the machined surface quality, and so on. Following that, Ahn et al. [60] and Kim et al. [61-63] developed the similar vertical stacked vibrators to improve the machining accuracy and fabricate the micro structures on various materials, such as nickel-plated mold steel, nickel alloy, nickel, brass, copper, and so on. Later on, another type of non-resonant elliptical vibrator named as parallel stacked PZT vibrator was developed at North Carolina State University [25]. Brehl et al. [25, 64-67] and Brocato et al. [68] applied this type of vibrator to the micro/nano structure fabrication on the hard plated copper and the stainless steel. Due to the decreasing of burr generation in EVC, Kim and Loh [59, 69] developed the similar parallel stacked vibrators to fabricate the micro V-grooves on the brass and the copper.
Fig. 3. Non-resonant elliptical vibrators with (a) vertical and (b) parallel stacked PZT [25, 27, 60-69].
For these recent years, the non-resonant 3D elliptical vibrator is also developed
for the special applications. For example, Lin et al. [70, 71] applied a non-resonant 3D elliptical vibrator to fabricate the optical freeform surface on the difficult-to-cut materials. The prediction model of the machined 3D surface topography was established in the theoretical analyzes and the experimental verifications. Although the improving of machined surface quality, the increasing of machining accuracy as well as the expending of tool life are confirmed by applying the developed elliptical vibrator, the fabrication of micro/nano structures have not been reported so far by applying the non-resonant 3D elliptical vibrator.
3.2 Micro/nano structure fabrication by applying the non-resonant EVC
3.2.1 Application of vertical stacked vibrator in micro/nano machining
Shamoto and Moriwaki [27] invented the vertical stacked vibrator to investigate
the machining performances of the EVC. Following that, this kind of vibrator is mainly used for the investigations of micro/nano structure fabrication in Korea. Kim and Loh [63] applied the vertical stacked vibrator to the pyramid patterns machining, as shown in Fig.4.
Fig. 4. Pyramid patterns fabricated by OC and EVC [63].
The vibrator works at a frequency of 18 kHz and a circle vibration locus of 1 μm0-p.
A micro cutting tool with a trapezoidal shape is used. The copper is machined by OC and EVC respectively. The pyramid patterns formed by the OC is deformed seriously and filled with burrs. In contrast, a smooth and accurate surface can be obtained because of the small cutting forces and the burr suppression in the EVC process. Additionally, the pyramid patterns are also fabricated on the brittle material of nickel. Instead of forming burrs in machining of the plastically materials, the brittle nature of nickel made the microstructures fractured in OC. In EVC process, the tool cuts the surface that is finished in the previous vibration cycle. Thus, the actual depth of cut becomes extremely thin as compared with the nominal depth of cut. Because of this process, the actual depth of cut becomes smaller than the critical value for ductile machining due to the size effect in fracture toughness, resulting in significant improvement of nominal critical depth of cut for ductile machining of brittle materials.
Hence, the pyramid patterns were successfully fabricated on the brittle material of nickel in ductile mode by applying EVC. Following this work, they applied V-shape SCD to fabricate the micro V-grooves and pyramid structures on brass, nickel-plated mold steel, nickel alloy, Inconel, and so on. As comparing with the OC, the machined surface quality and the form accuracy are much better in EVC. Figure 5 shows some samples fabricated by Kim and Loh [61, 62]. These facts indicate that the EVC is effective to suppress the burr generation and to attain better surface quality in micro/nano machining of plastically metal materials, alloy materials, brittle materials as well as steel materials.
Fig.5. Micro V-grooves and pyramid structures fabricated by OC and EVC [61, 62].
3.2.2 Application of parallel stacked vibrator in micro/nano machining
The parallel stacked vibrator has the same working mechanism as the vertical
stacked vibrator. The parallel stacked vibrator was developed at North Carolina State University, and mainly applied to the micro/nano structure fabrication in USA and Korea. Brehl et al. [64-67] reported that some complex micro/nano structures have been successfully manufactured by applying the parallel stacked vibrator, as shown in Fig.6. The workpiece material in Fig.6 (a-c) is hard plated copper, and the stainless steel is adopted in Fig.6 (d). The vibrator works at a frequency range of 1-4 kHz when fabricating these structures. Due to the decreasing of cutting forces and tool wear, all of the micro/nano structures have the burr free edge and high forming accuracy. Moreover, Brocatoet al. [68] experimentally clarified that the small chip size and the
elliptical vibration motion of cutting tool result in the lack of burring occurs in micro machining of copper. A similar micro/nano structure as Figure 6(c) shown is also fabricated with the length of 0.9 mm, the width of 0.6 mm and a height of 350 nm. Brehl et al. [64] combined the motion of the machine tool and the geometry of the dynamitic vibration locus, and fabricated an array of micro structures with concave sculpted surfaces in each vibration cycle. Kim and Loh [59] experimentally verified the shear angle is increased in EVC, which resulting in the decrease of cutting forces and chip thickness. And then, they applied a sharp tool edge to grooving the copper for the applications in optical devices. The machining boundary was precisely machined without obvious plastic deformation and burr generation. With the advantageous of EVC, Li et al. [72] also used the similar vibrator to fabricate the burr-free micro grooves for the optical application.
Fig. 6. Micro/nano structures fabricated by the parallel stacked vibrator [64-67].
As introduced in this section, the trajectory of the vibration locus can be
controlled easily and precisely in the non-resonant elliptical vibrator. The micro/nano structures can be fabricated in several workpiece materials by decreasing the cutting forces and the burr generation. Although the non-resonant vibrator has a relatively simpler design and their vibration parameters can be adjusted conveniently, it has a lower mechanical stiffness and a lower vibration frequency. The machining efficiency is lower due to the lower nominal cutting speed adopted. With the increase of vibration frequency, the vibration locus becomes unstable as reported and shown in the
literature published by Kim and Loh [59]. Moreover, the non-resonant elliptical vibrator is rarely applied to the micro/nano machining of high-hardness molding materials, e.g., hardened steel and tungsten carbide, so far. In order to attain a higher machining efficiency in the industrial application, the tool needs to be vibrated at a higher frequency, for example ultrasonic frequency by exciting the resonant modes of the vibrator. This type of vibrator is named as resonant elliptical vibrator. The benefits of high vibration frequency and high stiffness can be obtained by the resonant elliptical vibrator, which is advantageous to the efficient micro/nano machining of high-hardness material. However, the special design of the vibrator is required and the vibration locus needs to be controlled precisely because of the nature of the resonant vibrations and the phase lag between the excitation and the mechanical response. The already developed resonant elliptical vibrators and their applications in micro/nano machining are to be explained in the following section in detail.
4. Resonant elliptical vibration cutting
4.1 Development of the resonant elliptical vibrator
4.1.1 Elliptical vibrator utilizing two bending modes
The first resonant ultrasonic elliptical vibrator developed in 1995 by Moriwaki and
Shamoto [73], as shown in Fig.7. It is vibrated at its first resonant mode of bending in two vertical directions by applying the sinusoidal voltage to the PZTs, whose resonant frequency is 20 kHz. The amplitude of the vibration is magnified by the step horns, and maximized at the tool tip. Moriwaki and Shamoto [73] also clarified that the difficulties in design of the resonant ultrasonic elliptical vibrator, such as the optimum shape of the horn, the position of the supporting points, heat generation, and so on.
Fig. 7. Resonant elliptical vibrator with the first resonant mode of bending [73].
With the development of the ultrasonic resonant elliptical vibrator, a new vibrator
with the third resonant mode of bending was designed by Shamoto and Moriwaki [45], and used to the micro/nano machining of hardened steel by applying the SCD tool. Figure 8 shows a schematic illustration of the ultrasonic elliptical vibration tool and its third resonant mode of bending. The vibrator is resonated elliptically at about 20 kHz by exciting the two piezoelectric plates with some phase shift.
Fig. 8. Resonant elliptical vibrator with the third resonant mode of bending [45].
In order to improve the shape accuracy by applying the EVC, a new control
system is developed to stabilize the elliptical vibration locus. The above mentioned vibrator is modified slightly by attaching two small PZT plates as feedback sensors [74]. Figure 9 shows the modified vibrator and its control system. The interference between the two directional vibrations is efficiently deceased. It is advantageous to improve the machining accuracy especially in the micro/nano structure fabrication. Following the above researches, the similar bending mode vibrator was also manufactured by Lee et al. [75] for micro-grooving the brittle materials. It resonates at about 20 kHz by exciting two multilayer PZTs with a 90 degree phase shift. Xu et al. [55] also designed a similar vibrator in Fig. 2 for the machining of fibre-reinforced polymer (FRP) composites. The vibrator works at the anti-resonant frequencies of the third-bending-mode of 17.43 kHz in two vertical directions.
Fig. 9. Modified elliptical vibrator with the third resonant mode of bending and its control system [74].
4.1.2 Elliptical vibrator utilizing longitudinal and bending modes
In order to attain higher machining efficiency in EVC, the tool vibrated frequency
and the vibration amplitudes need to be improved for the industrial applications. A commercial ultrasonic elliptical vibrator [49, 76, 77] was developed for industrial use by the collaborative research between the Nagoya University and the Taga electric Co., Ltd. The vibrator can be actuated by exciting PZT actuators that re sandwiched with metal cylindrical parts, as shown in Fig.10 [49]. The sandwiched structure has many advantages, such as the high output power, easy to be designed and
assembled. Since the vibrator is designed to have the same resonant frequencies in the second resonant mode of longitudinal vibration and the fifth resonant mode of bending vibration, it can generate large longitudinal and bending vibrations simultaneously at the same ultrasonic frequency of 39 kHz by exciting the actuators. This kind of vibrator becomes compact and convenient for the industrial applications. Suzuki et al. [49] applied this vibrator to the micro/nano machining of tungsten alloy, which is a kind of typical molding materials in the optical industry. With the same type of vibrator, Nath et al. [52-54] also carried out several experimental investigations on elliptical vibration cutting of sintered tungsten carbide by applying the polycrystallinediamond (PCD). Zhang et al. [48] conducted further investigations on machining performance of hardened steel using PCD tools. It is confirmed that the elliptical vibration is kept constant precisely and this vibrator can be used for ultra-precision machining in industrial applications. Moreover, some other similar vibrators are also reported in the published literatures. For example, Song et al. [57] fabricated an elliptical vibrator with a resonant frequency of approximately 15 kHz for mirror finishing of Co-Cr-Mo alloy by applying the SCD. This vibrator works at the first resonant mode of longitudinal vibration and the third resonant mode of bending vibration. With the same vibration mode in the bending and the longitudinal directions, another elliptical vibrator is fabricated by Zhou and Hu [78]. It has a resonant frequency of 20 kHz, and applied to the precision machining of hardened steel by applying the SCD.
Fig. 10. Commercial ultrasonic elliptical vibrator with the longitudinal and bending modes [49].
Based on the resonant longitudinal-bending vibration mode, some other
ultrasonic vibrators were also development for the precision machining. Li and Zhang [79] presented an asymmetrical structural model of the ultrasonic elliptical vibration
transducer, which compounding the longitudinal-bending vibration modes at a resonant frequency of 22.5 kHz. Although this vibrator has only the longitudinal excitation, the transducer can generate a longitudinal-bending compound vibration mode with the special design of the asymmetrical structure. With a ultrasonic generator and an air-cooled piezoelectric converter, a similar vibrator with the vibration frequency of 40 kHz was proposed by Brinksmeier and Gläbe [80]. They have successfully applied this kind of vibrator to the precision machining of carbon steel by using of SCD. Moreover, Guo and Ehmann [81, 82] developed a resonant mode vibrator for the texturing process. The design is inspired by the development of the ultrasonic motor [83]. The vibrator is mainly composed of two bolt-clamped Langevin transducers, as shown in Fig.11. At the same resonant frequency of 28 kHz, the system works at the first normal and the second tangential vibration modes. The vibration frequency and the vibration amplitude can be adjusted by controlling the length of the mass.
Fig. 11. Ultrasonic elliptical vibrator composed of two bolt-clamped Langevin transducers [81].
The conventional elliptical vibrator was developed by combining the
bending-bending or the longitudinal-bending vibration modes. The vibration locus is generated in the fixed planes, which are roughly perpendicular to the vibrator axes. With further development of the EVC process, Shamoto et al. [84-86] developed a three-degrees-of-freedom (3DOF) ultrasonic elliptical vibration tool. Combining the
Moreover, a micro cylindrical part with a high aspect ratio of about 18 is
fabricated on the hardened steel due to the extremely small cutting forces in the EVC process. The micro cylindrical part fabricated by Shamoto and Moriwaki [45] is shown in Fig.13.
Fig. 13. Microphotograph of the fabricated micro cylindrical part [45].
With the same vibrator, Suzuki et al. [46] carried out the ultra-precision micro
grooving of hardened steel for a front light panel of LCD. The photographs of the mirror surface with micro grooves and the detailed SEM image of the micro grooves are shown in Fig.14.
Fig. 14. (a) Mirror surface with micro grooves and (b) the SEM image of fabricated micro grooves on hardened steel [46].
A series of grooving experiments are also conducted on brittle materials by
Suzuki et al. [87, 88] utilizing SCD tools. Figure 15 shows the micro grooves fabricated on the tungsten carbide and the calcium fluoride. The grooves formed by the OC are filled with brittle defects, while the smooth surface is obtained by the EVC
with the same cutting conditions. Especially in the grooving of soda-lime glass, Suzuki et al. [87, 88] clarified that not only the critical depth of cut is increased, but also the machining accuracy are improved due of the small cutting forces in the EVC process.
Fig. 15. Micro grooving of tungsten carbide and calcium fluoride by applying OC and EVC [87, 88].
Additionally, the sophisticated micro/nano structures are also successfully
fabricated by Shamoto and Suzuki [89, 90] on the dies and molds made of hardened steel. Figure 16 shows the micro trapezoidal structures and the micro Fresnel lens fabricated on the hardened steel by applying EVC. A high surface quality with the surface roughness less than 80 nmp-v is achieved without the visible shape deformation and burr generation. Moreover, the resonant ultrasonic elliptical vibrator with two bending modes is also used in other applications. For example, Lee et al. [75] grooved the glass and planar light wave circuits for optical fiber insertion by EVC. The micro grooves with smooth machined surface and non-chipped edges can be obtained, which is optimum for the fiber insertion. Ammouri and Hamade [58] developed a special bi-directional elliptical vibration actuator, which is successfully
applied to the fabrication of micro channels on Plexiglas.
Fig. 16. (a) Micro trapezoidal structures and (b) micro Fresnel lens fabricated on hardened steel [90].
4.2.2 Application of longitudinal and bending modes vibrator in micro/nano
machining
In this section, the micro/nano structure fabrications will be introduced by
applying the resonant ultrasonic elliptical vibrator with the longitudinal and bending modes in Figure 10. Suzuki et al. [49] firstly applied this vibrator to the micro/nano machining of ultra-precision molds made of tungsten alloy for the optical glass molding. A prism, a small spherical lens and an array of micro V-grooves are successfully fabricated by the EVC, as shown in Fig.17. Figure 18 shows the SEM image of the V-groove surface and the microphotograph of the used tool cutting edge. Because of the small cutting forces and no visible adhesion of the tungsten material to the cutting tool, sharp edges of the cutting tool keep stable in the EVC process. Moreover, high surface quality can be obtaioned due to the reduction of the brittle fracture generation on the machined surface. Following that, the V-grooved mold was also successfully applied to the molding of borosilicate glass BK7 for the mass production.
Fig. 18. (a) SEM image of the V-groove surface and (b) the microphotograph of the used tool cutting edge [49].
Moreover, an ultra-precision micro grooving by using the longitudinal-bending
vibrator was conducted by Shamoto and Suzuki [39], as shown in Fig.19. The accurate trapezoidal groove, whose shape is transformed from the micro tool cutting edge, is obtained on the hardened steel without the visible shape deteriorations.
Fig. 19. Micro trapezoidal grooves fabricated on hardened steel [39].
4.2.3 Amplitude control sculpturing method in micro/nano machining
Based on the above explorations, it is confirmed that the micro/nano structure
can be precisely fabricated by EVC equipped with the SCD cutting tools. Diamond cutting is crucial for the fabrication of micro/nano-structured surfaces, either for direct machining of the parts or making of molds for their mass production. Commercial diamond cutting machines are generally available for machining axisymmetric or free-form surfaces [91, 92], e.g. sphere and cone shape with optical-quality surface finish. However, due to the large moving mass, it is time consuming for the fabrication of micro-structured surfaces in practical application. To overcome this shortcoming, combination of the conventional diamond cutting and the FTS technology enables highly-efficient fabrication of micro/nano structures in a variety of applications [93-97]. Based on the successful cutting performance of EVC in practical applications, Suzuki et al. [28, 98, 99] explored further possibilities of functional surface machining on difficult-to-cut materials by applying EVC, and proposed a unique micro/nano sculpturing method, as shown in Fig. 20. In this proposed method, the vibration amplitude of the elliptical vibration is actively controlled while machining. Because of this amplitude control, the depth of cut can be changed rapidly without FTS but as being controlled by the conventional FTS technology. In other words, the EVC technology is already equipped with a FTS function by itself. This technology combines the benefits of EVC and FTS, which enables highly-efficient fabrication of micro/nano structures on the difficult-to-cut materials.
Fig. 20. Amplitude control sculpturing method in EVC [28, 98, 99].
Figure 21 illustrates the developed elliptical vibrator and its control system. It was
designed based on the already introduced vibrator in Fig.10. The vibrator is designed to have the same resonant frequencies in the second resonant mode of longitudinal vibration and the fifth resonant mode of bending vibration. The elliptical vibration can be obtained conveniently at the diamond tool tip with a frequency of about 36.2 kHz. The gain of the amplifier can be controlled by an external input in the developed system, and thus the exciting voltage supplied to the actuator is changed. The amplitude is, consequently, controlled by the external input as shown in Fig. 21. Mean-to-peak amplitudes can be controlled arbitrarily to change within 0-2 μm and within a bandwidth of about 300 Hz by external command voltage. Suzuki et al. [28, 98, 99] also presented several kinds of micro/nano textured patterns fabricated on hardened steel, as shown in Fig. 22 (a). The similar micro/nano structures were also successfully fabricated in ductile mode on the tungsten carbide by applying the amplitude control sculpturing method, as shown in Fig. 22 (b) [100, 101].
Fig. 21. Elliptical vibrator with the external input for amplitude control [28, 98, 99].
Fig. 22. Textured patterns fabricated on hardened steel and tungsten carbide [28, 100].
By applying the proposed amplitude control sculpturing method, it was
experimentally confirmed the nano structure with a machining accuracy of about ±1 nm can be machined in the depth of cut direction [102]. Several nano patterns were successfully fabricated on hardened steel. Figure 23 shows a trapezoidal structures machined by the amplitude corresponding to 25 nm structure height with a pitch value of 2 μm [102, 103]. In what follows, textured grooves with a 20 nm structure height were also sculptured on a hardened steel workpiece, as shown in Fig. 24 [103, 104]. The feasibility of nano structure sculpturing was confirmed by applying the proposed
amplitude control sculpturing method in EVC.
Fig. 23. Trapezoidal structures with 25 nm structural height and 2 μm pitch value [102, 103].
Fig. 24. Nano structures with 20 nm structural height and 1 μm pitch value [103, 104].
In order to attain the arbitrary sculpturing, Suzuki et al. [28, 98, 99] also
developed an unique ultra-precision micro/nano sculpturing system. The vibration amplitude in the depth of cut direction is precisely controlled in synchronization with the cutting feed motion of the ultra-precision machine tool. The developed system was applied to the micro/nano sculpturing of arbitrary gray scale images. The gray values of 8 bits (256 gradations) in pixels were converted into the amplitude control commands. A gray scale image of Prof. Shamoto [28, 98, 99, 105, 106] was successfully fabricated on the hardened steel as a nanometer scale sculpture, as
shown in Fig. 25.
Fig. 25. An arbitrary nanometer scale sculpture fabricated on hardened steel [28, 98, 99, 105, 106].
With the developed sculpturing system, some other sophisticated micro/nano
structures were also fabricated on the hardened steel. For example, sinusoidal commands to control the vibration amplitude were input to the elliptical vibration control system during machining and the phase of the sinusoidal commands was changed by 180 degrees in every cutting feed, so that hexagonal dimple patterns can be sculptured based on vibration conditions, cutting conditions and tool geometries, as shown in Fig. 26 (a) [28, 98, 99, 103]. On the other hand, if the height position along the nominal pick feed direction was controlled by utilizing positioning of the ultra-precision machine tool or changing the amplitude controlling voltage, an angle grid surface can be manufactured as shown in Fig. 26 (b).
Fig. 26. (a) Hexagonal dimple patterns and (b) angle grid fabricated on hardened steel [28, 98, 99, 103, 104].
In order to improve the machining accuracy, a compensation method for
decreasing the machining error, which is caused by the disagreement of the amplitude command shape and the envelope of the cutting edge trajectory, was also proposed by applying the amplitude control sculpturing method [103, 104]. In each vibration cycle, the vibration locus is controlled to be tangential to the target profile. Some deep micro/nano structures with a large ratio of structure height to pitch length can be accurately fabricated. As shown in Fig. 27, an angle grid surface with the structure height and wave length of 1 μm and 10 μm in the nominal cutting direction was fabricated with a maximum machining error of 22.6 nmp-v.
Fig. 27. A deep angle grid surface with the structure height and wave length of 1 μm and 10 μm [103, 104].
4.2.4 Elliptical vibration texturing method in micro/nano machining
In this paper, the EVC process was introduced in Fig.2. A part of elliptical
vibration trajectory is superimposed on the machined surface in each vibration cycle, resulting in regular undulation on the finished surface. In order to decrease the undulation amplitude and to obtain better surface roughness, a low nominal cutting speed condition is generally applied. In contrast to general EVC, Guo and Ehmann [81, 82] proposed to apply this unique nature of undulation generation onto surface texturing. They developed an elliptical vibrator as shown in Fig.11 and proposed a texturing method by utilizing EVC process, where by applying relatively higher nominal cutting speed with constant elliptical vibration amplitude, large undulation is superimposed in each vibration as a texture. As the nominal cutting speed is relatively high, machining efficiency is also better as compared with that in general EVC. Guo and Ehmann [81, 82] fabricated a series of dimple patterns on the aluminum 6061 with a diamond cutting tool, as shown in Fig. 28. They reported that the functional surfaces with the designed dimple patterns have the properties of friction reduction, reflective, antibacterial, and so on. They also fabricated the micro/nano textured surface inside the micro channels to enhance the anisotropic wettability by applying the texturing method.
Fig. 28. Dimple patterns fabricated on the aluminum 6061 by applying the elliptical vibration texturing [81, 82].
With increasing of the nominal cutting speed, the tool may not be separated with
the workpiece material in each vibration cycle. Figure 29 [82] illustrates a typical tool trajectory by applying the proposed elliptical vibration texturing method to the dimple structure machining. Every dimple structure is generated by the tool vibration trajectory in each vibration cycle. With decreasing of the nominal depth of cut,
uncontinuous dimple structures can be fabricated. Lu et al. [107] fabricated these dimple structures on the aluminum cylindrical surfaces to control the surface wettability, as shown in Fig. 30. The water droplet contact angle is 81 deg on the textured surface. Moreover, Guo et al. and Lu et al. [82, 107] reported that the micro/nano channels can also be quickly obtained by overlapping the dimples in a certain direction. The theoretical analysis and the experimental verifications on the generation of different patterns are investigated in detail [107-109]. Recently, only some simple and regular structures can be fabricated by this method. Moreover, as the tool may not be separated with workpiece material in each vibration cycle, the elliptical vibration texturing process is similar as the ordinary cutting equipped with the FTS. In contrast to the general EVC, some advantageous, i.e., the tool cooling, the cutting forces decreasing, the burr reduction, et al., are not standing out in the elliptical vibration texturing process. This texturing technology is not yet applied to the micro/nano diamond machining of difficult-to-cut materials, such as hardened steel, tungsten carbide, tungsten allay, and so on.
Fig. 29. A typical tool trajectory in dimple patterns fabrication by applying elliptical vibration texturing method [82].
Fig. 30. Fabricated dimple structures for the surface wettability controlling [107].
5. Analysis of the applications and developments in EVC technology
EVC is a kind of novel intermittent cutting process. The chip is formed in each
vibration cycle, and pulled out by the rake face of cutting tool, resulting in significant decreases of the chip thickness and the average cutting forces [27, 40, 41]. With these benefits, it is theoretically and experimentally clarified that the burr generation, the defect propagation and the regenerative chatter vibration can be suppressed [42-44] in the EVC process. Moreover, due to the separation in each vibration cycle, the contact surfaces of the cutting edge and the workpiece can be exposed into the surrounding gas and/or the cutting fluid, resulting in cooling of the tool and workpieces. As a result, not only the thermo-chemical wear but also the adhesion and diffusion can be suppressed efficiently. Based on the successful cutting performances of EVC, a unique micro/nano sculpturing method is proposed for the functional surface machining in the practical applications. The EVC technology is equipped with a FTS function by itself. Furthermore, based on the kinematic model of the vibration locus, the dimple structure can also be efficiently fabricated in each vibration cycle. The excellent characters of EVC are promoting the development of EVC technology in the micro/nano machining process. This technology is successfully tested in industries for ultra-precision diamond cutting of both plastic metal materials and difficult-to-cut materials as introduced in Section 2. The EVC technology is expected to precisely fabricate the microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) with the small cutting forces and burr suppression [64, 67]. The fabricated micro pyramids can also significantly improve the cooling performance of a super-heated wall in MEMS [110]. In optical industry, EVC can be directly used for the micro/nano machining of optical glass materials [87, 88]. Some sophisticated micro/nano diffractive gratings may be fabricated on the digital lens, which is advantageous to guide the beam path to obtain high-performance imaging, concentration, illumination and other applications. For the mass production of glass elements, the EVC technology can also be applied to the mold materials machining in the glass molding industry, such as hardened steel [45-48], tungsten alloy [49], sintered tungsten carbide [50-54] and so on. In bioengineering, the mirror finishing of Co-Cr-Mo alloy by applying EVC [57] reduces the abrasive resistance, making it suitable for the use in artificial joints. In self-cleaning, the micro/nano channels and dimples can be efficiently fabricated by applying the elliptical vibration texturing method [82, 107]. It allows dirt and water to simply wash off and decreases the cost by nonuse of cleaning chemicals. Moreover, with the development of ultra-precision engineering, precision measurement in positioning of the machine tool is necessary. The micro/nano-structured surface with
sinusoidal grids can be accurately fabricated by applying amplitude controlling method in EVC [103, 104], which can be used as a surface encoder to the measurement of multi-axis position. In manufacturing industry, steel material is widely used for the mechanical elements in the precision machine tool. The EVC technology can be directly applied to planing or texturing the steel materials with a diamond tool. As a moving part, the steel elements with the textured surface could be regarded as equipping a set of micro-bearings distributed over the sliding surface [111, 112], which is advantageous to reducing the friction between sliding surfaces and improving the motion accuracy and working life. As aforementioned, the EVC technology has been used in a series of industrial applications so far.
However, there are also some restrictions in the industrial use of EVC technology.
In general EVC process, a part of elliptical vibration trajectory is superimposed on the machined surface in each vibration, resulting in regular undulation on the finished surface, as shown in Fig. 2. In order to decrease the undulation amplitude and to obtain better surface roughness, a low nominal cutting speed condition is generally applied. The machining efficiency is restricted as compared with the OC process. For example, the nominal cutting speed is usually set to be much lower than the maximum vibration speed ma in the nominal cutting direction. There is:

where is the angular frequency of the tool vibration, is the mean-to-peak amplitude in the nominal cutting direction. And also, the height variation range of the fabricated micro/nano structures is restricted by the mean-to-peak vibration amplitude along the depth of cut direction both in the amplitude control sculpturing process and the elliptical vibration texturing process. In order to improve the machining efficiency and enlarge the height variation range of the fabricated micro/nano structures, the high power elliptical vibrators with the larger vibration frequency and vibration amplitudes should be developed in the future.
Additionally, although the resonant elliptical vibrator can obtain the high vibration
frequency and high stiffness, there are some difficulties should be solved in the vibrator manufacturing process. Especially the optimum shape of the horn, the position of the supporting points, the interfere between the two directional vibrations and the heat generation need to be considered. Moreover, the actual cutting distance becomes much longer than the tool feed distance in one vibration cycle, as shown in Fig. 2 in the EVC process. The tool damage progress in EVC has a strong relation with the actual cumulative cutting distance [100]. Thus, appropriate conditions need to be selected to make a good balance in the surface quality and the tool life when machining the difficult-to-cut materials. Furthermore, the high cost SCD tool is usually
applied to the EVC process for the precision machining. In order to achieve the low cost precision machining, the low cost cutting tools, i.e., polycrystalline diamond (PCD) tools [48, 52-54], cubic boron nitride (CBN) tools [62], diamond coated and titanium nitride (TiN) coated carbide tools [113], have been tested in tungsten carbide and hardened steel machining by applying the EVC technology. With the deeply theoretical and experimental clarifications, it is hoped that the ordinary industrial cutting tools equipped with the EVC process can be applied to the low cost and high precision engineering.
6. Conclusion
EVC is a kind of potential advanced technologies in the micro/nano machining of
various materials, especially the difficult-to-cut materials. In the present review paper, the development of different elliptical vibrators is firstly introduced in detail. The non-resonant elliptical vibrator is vibrated by two separately PZT arranged at a right angle, where the vibration locus is generated on the tool tip by converting the linear expansion and contraction of the PZT. Although the non-resonant vibrator has a relatively simpler design, it has a lower mechanical stiffness and a lower vibration frequency. To overcome this problem, the resonant elliptical vibrator with high stiffness, high accuracy and high vibration frequency at the nature resonant modes is proposed. The optimum shape of the horn, the position of the supporting points, the interfere between the two directional vibrations and the heat generation need to be considered in the vibrator manufacturing process. Following that, the micro/nano machining technologies are detailedly expatiated by applying the different types of elliptical vibrators. As EVC is a kind of novel intermittent cutting process, the chip is pulled out by the rake face of cutting tool in each vibration cycle, resulting in significant decreases of the chip thickness and the average cutting forces. It is theoretically and experimentally clarified that the burr generation and the defect propagation can be suppressed in the micro/nano machining process. Moreover, due to the separation in each vibration cycle, the contact surfaces of the cutting edge and the workpiece can be exposed into the surrounding gas and/or the cutting fluid, resulting in cooling of the tool and workpieces. As a result, not only the thermo-chemical wear but also the adhesion and diffusion between the workpiece and the cutting tool can be supressed efficiently. Ultra-precision micro/nano machining of difficult-to-cut materials, such as hardened steel, tungsten alloy, sintered tungsten carbide, fibre-reinforced polymer, Molybdenum, Co-Cr-Mo alloy, Plexiglas and other various materials, were realized by applying the EVC technology. Based on the successful cutting performance of EVC, a
unique amplitude control sculpturing method is proposed for the functional surface machining in the practical applications. The EVC technology is already equipped with a FTS function by itself. Furthermore, based on the kinematic model of the vibration locus, some dimple structure can also be efficiently fabricated in each vibration cycle by applying the elliptical vibration texturing method. The excellent characters of EVC are promoting the development of EVC technology in the micro/nano machining process. Finally, the current development trends of the EVC technology are also analyzed. In order to improve the machining efficiency and enlarge the height variation range of the fabricated micro/nano structures, the high power elliptical vibrators with the higher vibration frequency and larger vibration amplitudes should be developed in the future. And also, the low cost cutting tools are hoped to apply to the industrial EVC process to achieve the low cost and high precision machining. Additionally, the actual cumulative cutting distance should be considered to make a good balance in the surface quality and the tool life in the EVC process.

 As compared with the OC technology, the advantageous of EVC is clarified.
 The development of different elliptical vibrators is introduced in detail.
 The micro/nano machining technologies are expatiated by applying the different
types of elliptical vibrators.
 The current development trends of the EVC technology are analyzed.

metadata.abstractText: Textured surfaces with sophisticated micro/nano structures can provide interesting and advanced functions. In order to promote those unique functions into the practical use, high performance manufacturing technologies are required. Nowadays, elliptical vibration cutting (EVC) is attracting more and more attentions due to its excellent machining performances, especially the advantageous in the precision machining of difficult-to-cut materials. The emphasis on this literature review is the micro/nano machining technology by applying EVC. The development of the EVC technology is simply introduced, and then the advantageousness of EVC in the machining process is explored in detail. As following, the development of different EVC devices are introduced, and the applications of the micro/nano structure fabrication is detailedly expatiated by applying the different types of elliptical vibrators. By controlling the motion of the ultra-precision machine tool itself, the micro/nano structure can be accurately fabricated on various workpiece materials with the reduction of cutting forces, burr generation, tool wear, et al. in EVC process. Moreover, a unique amplitude control sculpturing method, where the depth of cut is arbitrary changed by controlling the vibration amplitude in the machining process, is introduced. By applying the amplitude control sculpturing method, ultra-precision micro/nano structures can be efficiently sculptured especially on the difficult-to-cut materials. Finally, the elliptical vibration texturing process is also explored in the fast micro/nano machining of the simple and regular structures. The EVC technology is expected to promote the development of micro/nano machining process in the actual industrial applications.
